Issues.Title: Input writing refactors
Issues.Body:
Includes some refactors around how we store input data internally. The result is that:
* We duplicate less information between the `TNode` and the directive definition.
* `DirectiveDef.inputs` has a consistent type no matter how an input is configured which makes it easier to reason about.
* We need less information in order to write to a directive's input.
* We can remove the `InputTransformsFeature`.
* We can remove the `DirectiveDef.inputTransforms` field.
* We no longer need to store input flags in `TNode.inputs`.
* We store 2 less values in the `TNode.initialInputs` data structure.
* We don't resolve the native element for property writes in production mode. In development mode it's only used for the `ng-reflect-` attributes.

Detailed list of changes:

### refactor(core): simplify how inputs are stored in the directive definition
Currently the values in `DirectiveDef.inputs` are either strings or arrays, depending if there are flags. This makes it a bit hard to work with, because each time it's read, the consumer needs to account for both cases.

These changes rework it so the values are always an arrays.

### refactor(core): remove inputTransforms from definition 
Removes the `inputTransform` from the directive definition since this information is already available on the `inputs`.

### refactor(compiler): remove input transforms feature 
An earlier refactor made the `InputTransformsFeature` a no-op so these changes remove the code that was generating it.

### refactor(core): remove flags from TNode.inputs 
The input flags are already available on the definition so we don't need to store them on `TNode.inputs`.

### refactor(core): simplify InitialInputs data structure
Reworks the `InitialInputs` data structure to only store a public name and initial value, resulting in less memory usage and making it easier to work with.

### refactor(core): refactor(core): avoid unnecessary lookup when writing inputs
Currently we resolve the DOM node when writing inputs up-front, because it's necessary for the `ng-reflect-` attributes. Since the attributes are dev-mode-only, we can move the resolution into the function that writes them so we can avoid the resolution when it's not used.

### refactor(core): add assertion to avoid writes to directive factories
Attempting to write to directive inputs before the directive is created can lead to subtle issues that won't necessarily trigger errors. These changes add an assertion to catch such issues earlier.

Issues.Title: ng19 Component Library Components not recognizing provider DatePipe
Issues.Body:
### Command serve ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description While migrating a Component Library to Angular 19 and removing NgModules, I encountered a runtime error stating "No provider for DatePipe", despite explicitly importing and providing DatePipe within the components that require it. Interestingly, the component library builds successfully without needing a module to provide DatePipe. However, the application only runs if I add DatePipe to the providers array in main.ts within my test harness. This shouldn’t be a requirement for a component library—I want to avoid tightly coupling the library to any consuming application in this way. ### Minimal Reproduction Here are the steps to reproduce the issue: ### **Steps to Reproduce the "No Provider for DatePipe" Error in Angular 19 Component Library** #### **1. Create a New Angular Component Library** - Generate a new Angular workspace with a library: ```sh ng new my-workspace --create-application=false cd my-workspace ng generate library my-lib ``` - Navigate to the `projects/my-lib` directory. #### **2. Create a Component That Uses `DatePipe`** - Inside `projects/my-lib/src/lib/`, create a new component: ```sh ng generate component date-display ``` - Modify `date-display.component.ts` to use `DatePipe`: ```typescript import { Component, Inject } from '@angular/core'; import { DatePipe } from '@angular/common'; @Component({ selector: 'lib-date-display', template: '

{{ today | date }}

', providers: [DatePipe] // Providing DatePipe here }) export class DateDisplayComponent { today = new Date(); constructor(private datePipe: DatePipe) { console.log(this.datePipe.transform(this.today, 'longDate')); } } ``` #### **3. Ensure `NgModule` is Removed (Standalone Component)** - Modify `date-display.component.ts` to make it a standalone component: ```typescript @Component({ selector: 'lib-date-display', standalone: true, template: '

{{ today | date }}

', providers: [DatePipe] // Providing DatePipe here }) export class DateDisplayComponent { today = new Date(); constructor(private datePipe: DatePipe) { console.log(this.datePipe.transform(this.today, 'longDate')); } } ``` #### **4. Build the Library** - Run: ```sh ng build my-lib ``` - The build should succeed without errors. #### **5. Create a Test Application** - Generate a new Angular application to test the library: ```sh ng generate application test-app ``` - Add the library to the application: ```sh ng add my-lib ``` #### **6. Use the Component in the Test Application** - Open `test-app/src/app/app.component.html` and add: ```html ``` - Open `test-app/src/app/app.component.ts` and import the standalone component: ```typescript import { Component } from '@angular/core'; import { DateDisplayComponent } from 'my-lib'; @Component({ selector: 'app-root', standalone: true, imports: [DateDisplayComponent], template: '' }) export class AppComponent {} ``` #### **7. Run the Application** ```sh ng serve test-app ``` - **Expected Behavior:** The app should run without issues. - **Actual Behavior:** A runtime error occurs: ``` Error: NG0203: No provider for DatePipe! ``` #### **8. Workaround: Add `DatePipe` to `main.ts`** - Modify `test-app/src/main.ts` to provide `DatePipe` globally: ```typescript import { bootstrapApplication } from '@angular/platform-browser'; import { AppComponent } from './app/app.component'; import { provideHttpClient } from '@angular/common/http'; import { DatePipe } from '@angular/common'; bootstrapApplication(AppComponent, { providers: [DatePipe] }); ``` - **Now the application runs correctly.** ### **Issue Summary** - The component library builds successfully. - Despite providing `DatePipe` at the component level, Angular still throws a "No Provider" error at runtime. - The app only works when `DatePipe` is provided at the application level (`main.ts`), which **forces tight coupling** between the library and the consuming application. ### **Expected Behavior** - Since `DatePipe` is provided in the standalone component, the app should not require an additional provider in `main.ts`. - The component library should be self-contained and not require the consuming application to explicitly provide `DatePipe`. Issues.Body:
The `@angular/build` package is now used directly within all newly created projects and replaces the previous usage of the `@angular-devkit/build-angular` package. This has the advantage of removing the need to install all of the Webpack related transitive dependencies contained within `@angular-devkit/build-angular` that are used to support the `browser` builder. This results in a significant reduction in both total dependency count and disk install size for new projects. New projects that would prefer to use the Webpack-based `browser` builder can still install the `@angular-devkit/build-angular` package within the workspace.

The `@angular/build@19.2.0-next.2` package currently has a total unpacked size of ~115 MB.

Issues.Body:
An `application` only variant of the `karma` builder found within the `@angular-devkit/build-angular` package is now available within the `@angular/build` package as `@angular/build:karma`. This builder will only use the `application` builder found within `@angular/build` and does not provide the `builderMode` option as `application` would be the only valid value. Testing behavior is effectively equivalent to using the `@angular-devkit/build-angular:karma` builder with the `builderMode` option set to `application`. However, several options have been adjusted:
* `builderMode` was removed
* `fileReplacements` legacy structure (`src`/`replaceWith`) removed
* `polyfills` only accepts an array of strings
* `loader` has been added
* `define` has been added
* `externalDependencies` has been added
* `sass` sub-option for `stylePreprocessorOptions` has been added

From an implementation perspective, the test finding logic and the application builder integration have been moved to the `@angular/build` package and reused by the `@angular-devkit/build-angular` package via the private export of `@angular/build`.

Issues.Title: add ng build cli option to mark extended diagnostics as errors
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

Currently there is an option to mark angular compiler warnings as errors by modifying `tsconfig.json`:
```
...
  "angularCompilerOptions": {
    "extendedDiagnostics": {
      "defaultCategory": "error"
    },
  }
...
```

For normal development (e.g. via `ng serve`), I don't want to have this option, as there might be issues (e.g. import errors) which are only temporary when editing a file.

But for the CI pipeline, the warnings should be treated as errors.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Add a CLI option (name of variable just a proposal) to treat extended diagnostics warnings as errors (like `-Werror` for C compilers):
```
ng build --extendedDiagnosticsWarnings=error
```
This would behave the same way as setting `angularCompilerOptions.extendedDiagnostics.defaultCategory` to the specified level

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Patching tsconfig in CI pipeline: this is a bit error-prone and requires additional tools in the CI image

Issues.Title: ci: replace `bazel run @npm2//:sync` with `bazel sync --only=repo`
Issues.Body:
In certain scenarios, running `bazel run @npm2//:sync` does not reliably update the aspect lock files. For example:

```
# Update the version in package.json
$ yarn bazel run @npm2//:sync  # Lock file is updated
$ git restore .aspect
$ yarn bazel run @npm2//:sync  # Lock file is NOT updated
```

Switching to `bazel sync --only=repo` guarantees that the lock file is consistently updated.

More context: https://angular-team.slack.com/archives/C042EU9T5/p1739398554132249

Issues.Title: [drag-drop] cdk-drag node is detached after element is dropped from one container to another
Issues.Body:
### Description

If the element is dropped from one container to another, a detached node is created because of `CdkDropList._dropListRef._draggables`.

### Reproduction

**StackBlitz link**: https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-vygnusmw

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Download the project from StackBlitz.
2. Start it and open in the Edge browser. Open the deprecated "Detached elements" tool.
3. Drag an item from the "To do" column to the "In progress" column and then to "Done".
4. Collect garbage in the "Detached elements" tool and check detached items.








### Expected Behavior

There are no detached nodes related to the cdk-drag element.

### Actual Behavior

There are 2 `cdk-drag-dragging` detached nodes. 

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c0fb8a7e-869d-4858-b1f0-b2d79177eb53)

The same result will be achieved if performed in Chrome, but more details can be seen in the Edge. If the "Analyze" button is clicked - you will get an id to the retainer (instead of the initial text "Object not found in memory anymore"). Double-clicking on it will show the retainer info. In this case, it's the `CdkDropList._dropListRef._draggables` array.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1f25936c-c259-46f6-955a-73de1381b42b)

**Some info after my analysis**: `_draggables` are set in the `DropListRef`'s `withItems` method.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/56971d06-deaf-4f0d-86b8-8e73101221ed)

While debugging I should have entered it via `_syncItemsWithRef`, but there's a `this._dropListRef.isDragging()` condition in the `removeItem` method. In my case, I've already dropped an item and it's no longer dragging. Therefore `_draggables` are not updated and there's a `cdk-drag` detached node because of that.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/65010937-ced3-4911-bd12-4ef965ab2085)

I'm not sure if that condition should be there at all, cause surely we need to sync items with ref **not only when dragging is in progress**. Here's a [link to the commit](https://github.com/angular/components/commit/d1a6ea74db0881001bf02ff113f269552effc4f6) where those changes were added.

For my project, I monkey-patched `removeItem` method and removed `isDragging()` condition. For us, the case when an item should be removed while dragging is not relevant.

### Environment

- Angular: 19.0.6
- CDK/Material: 19.0.0
- Browser(s): Chrome/Edge
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 11 Pro
